definitions: provide a store or shop with items for sale or distribution
accumulate and keep supplies or materials for future use or sale
provide a farm or area with animals for breeding or farming
examples: The store stocks organic produce from local farms
We need to stock the shelves before opening tomorrow
They stock enough food to last through the winter months
The restaurant stocks rare wines in their cellar
The farmer decided to stock the pond with trout
They stocked the ranch with cattle last spring

definitions: accumulate large quantities of goods or materials for future use or emergency
secretly accumulate weapons or military supplies for potential future conflict
examples: Companies stockpile raw materials before expected price increases
Many people stockpiled toilet paper during the pandemic
The nation was accused of stockpiling nuclear weapons illegally
Rebels stockpiled arms in hidden mountain caves

definitions: add coal or other fuel to a fire or furnace to maintain or increase heat
encourage or incite strong emotions or actions in people deliberately
examples: He stoked the fire to keep the cabin warm overnight
Workers stoked the furnace throughout the cold night
His comments stoked fears about economic recession
The media coverage stoked public anger about the scandal

definitions: tolerate or endure something unpleasant without showing displeasure or distress
accept or process difficult information or experiences mentally and emotionally
examples: She couldn't stomach the violence in the movie
I can't stomach his arrogant behavior anymore
It took time to stomach the reality of the diagnosis
He couldn't stomach the thought of leaving his hometown

definitions: walk with heavy forceful steps making loud sounds with the feet
crush or flatten something by stepping on it heavily and repeatedly
perform a lively dance with heavy stamping movements of the feet
examples: The angry teenager stomped up the stairs to her room
He stomped through the puddles in his boots
Don't stomp on the flowers in the garden
She accidentally stomped the bug on the floor
The crowd stomped to the rhythm of the music
They stomped their feet during the barn dance

definitions: throw stones at someone or something as punishment or attack
remove the hard seed or pit from fruit before eating or cooking
examples: In ancient times, criminals were sometimes stoned to death
The angry mob threatened to stone the building
Please stone the cherries before making the pie
She carefully stoned the olives for the salad

definitions: deliberately delay or obstruct a process or investigation by being uncooperative
refuse to answer questions or provide information to avoid revealing something
examples: The company stonewalled the investigation for months
Politicians often stonewall when asked difficult questions
The witness stonewalled during the entire interrogation
She stonewalled reporters who asked about her personal life

definitions: act as a subordinate who does unpleasant tasks for someone else
perform as a comedian's assistant who is the target of jokes
examples: He refused to stooge for the corrupt manager anymore
They hired him to stooge for the boss
He stooged for famous comedians in vaudeville shows
The actor stooged brilliantly in the slapstick routine

definitions: bend the head and shoulders forward and downward from an upright position
lower oneself morally or professionally to do something considered beneath dignity
examples: She stooped to pick up the dropped keys
The old man stooped as he walked through the doorway
I won't stoop to their level of dishonesty
He stooped to begging when he lost everything

definitions: come to a halt and cease moving or traveling forward
prevent something from happening or block something from continuing
pause or stay briefly at a place during a journey
cease doing an activity or discontinue a habit permanently
examples: The train stopped at every station along the route
Stop the car at the red light
The new law will stop companies from polluting rivers
Nothing could stop him from achieving his dreams
We stopped at a restaurant for lunch
They stopped in Paris for two days
She stopped smoking after her health scare
Please stop making that annoying noise

definitions: close or seal a container with a cork or plug device
act as a goalkeeper preventing goals in sports like soccer
examples: She carefully stoppered the wine bottle after dinner
Make sure to stopper all the test tubes properly
He stoppered for the local football team
The substitute had to stopper when the goalkeeper was injured

definitions: keep things in a special place for use in the future
save data or information in computer memory or electronic devices
gradually accumulate supplies or resources over time for later use
examples: Store the winter clothes in the attic until next year
We store our tools in the garage
The computer stores all files on the hard drive
Cloud services store your data remotely
Squirrels store nuts for the winter months
The body stores excess calories as fat

definitions: attack a place suddenly and forcefully to capture or enter it
move somewhere quickly and angrily showing strong emotion
express violent anger through shouting and aggressive behavior
examples: The troops stormed the enemy fortress at dawn
Police stormed the building to rescue the hostages
She stormed out of the meeting in frustration
He stormed into the office demanding answers
The coach stormed at the referee about the bad call
She stormed for hours about the unfair treatment

definitions: pack or store things carefully and compactly in a specific place
hide someone or something secretly in a vehicle or container
examples: The crew stowed the cargo in the ship's hold
Please stow your luggage in the overhead compartment
The refugee stowed away on a cargo ship
They stowed the weapons in a hidden compartment

definitions: sit or stand with one leg on each side of something
extend across or be positioned on both sides of something
avoid committing clearly to either of two positions or options
examples: The cowboy straddled his horse before riding off
She straddled the bench to reach both sides
The town straddles the border between two states
The bridge straddles the wide river
Politicians often straddle controversial issues before elections
The company straddles both consumer and business markets

definitions: make something straight by removing curves or bends from it
become straight or return to an upright position after being bent
put something in proper order or correct problems in a situation
examples: She straightened her hair with a flat iron
The worker straightened the bent metal rod
His back straightened when he heard his name called
The road straightens after the sharp curve
We need to straighten out this misunderstanding immediately
He straightened his life after years of problems

definitions: pull or stretch something tightly by applying force to it
injure a muscle or body part by stretching or overusing it
pour liquid through a filter to remove solid pieces
make great physical or mental effort to achieve something difficult
examples: The weight strained the rope until it nearly broke
Don't strain the fabric when washing it
He strained his back lifting heavy boxes
The athlete strained a hamstring during the race
Strain the pasta water into the sink
She strained the juice to remove the pulp
Students strain to understand complex mathematical concepts
She strained to hear the conversation

definitions: leave someone in a difficult situation without help or transport
cause a boat or ship to be stuck on shore or shallow water
examples: The cancelled flight stranded passengers at the airport overnight
Don't strand me here without a way home
The storm stranded several boats on the beach
High tide stranded the whale on the sand

definitions: kill someone by squeezing their throat to prevent breathing
prevent something from developing or succeeding by restricting it severely
examples: The victim was strangled with a rope
He tried to strangle his attacker in self-defense
Excessive regulations strangle small business growth
High taxes strangle economic development

definitions: fasten or secure something using straps or similar binding devices
beat someone with a leather strap as punishment
examples: Strap the luggage securely to the roof rack
The nurse strapped the patient to the gurney
Teachers used to strap students for misbehavior
He was strapped for breaking the rules

definitions: move away from the correct path or intended route accidentally
move away from the main subject or topic during conversation or thought
examples: The hikers strayed from the marked trail in the fog
Don't let the children stray too far from camp
The discussion strayed from the original agenda
His mind strayed during the boring lecture

definitions: move very quickly in a specified direction like a flash
mark something with long thin lines or bands of color
run naked through a public place as a prank or protest
examples: The meteor streaked across the night sky
Cars streaked past on the highway
Tears streaked her makeup down her face
He streaked the canvas with bold colors
A fan streaked across the football field
Students streaked through campus during finals week

definitions: flow steadily and continuously in a current or stream
transmit or receive data continuously over the internet in real time
move in large numbers continuously in the same direction
examples: Water streamed down the mountain after the rain
Sunlight streamed through the window
We stream movies instead of downloading them
The concert will stream live on social media
Fans streamed into the stadium for the game
Refugees streamed across the border

definitions: make an organization or process more efficient by simplifying or eliminating unnecessary elements
design something with a smooth shape to reduce air or water resistance
examples: The company streamlined operations to reduce costs
We need to streamline the approval process
Engineers streamlined the car body for better fuel efficiency
They streamlined the hull design for speed

definitions: make something physically stronger or more resistant to force or pressure
make something more powerful effective or intense in quality or degree
become stronger or more powerful through growth or development
examples: Exercise strengthens your muscles and bones
They strengthened the bridge with steel supports
The new evidence strengthened their legal case
This partnership will strengthen our market position
The storm strengthened into a hurricane overnight
Their relationship strengthened over the years

definitions: make something longer or wider by pulling it from opposite ends
extend parts of the body to full length or to relieve stiffness
extend or spread over an area or period of time
exaggerate or extend the truth beyond what is strictly accurate
examples: Don't stretch the sweater or it will lose its shape
The rubber band stretched until it snapped
She stretched her arms above her head
Athletes stretch before exercising to prevent injury
The desert stretches for hundreds of miles
The project will stretch over several months
He stretched the truth about his qualifications
That story stretches credibility too far

definitions: walk with long decisive steps in a specified direction
cross or step over something with a single long step
examples: She strode confidently into the boardroom
The tall man strode quickly down the street
He easily strode the narrow stream
The giant could stride the valley in one step

definitions: hit someone or something forcefully with hand or weapon
refuse to work as a form of organized protest for better conditions
suddenly discover something valuable like oil or gold
suddenly come into someone's mind as an idea or thought
make a strong impression on someone or affect them emotionally
examples: Lightning struck the tall tree during the storm
The boxer struck his opponent with a powerful punch
Workers will strike if demands aren't met
The union struck for better wages
They struck oil after months of drilling
Prospectors struck gold in the mountains
A brilliant idea suddenly struck him
It struck me that we were going the wrong way
Her beauty struck him immediately
The similarity between them strikes everyone

definitions: put things onto a string or thread them together in sequence
arrange or stretch something in a line between two points
connect things together in a series or sequence
examples: She strung beads to make a necklace
String the lights around the Christmas tree
They strung a rope between the two trees
Workers strung cable across the valley
The company strung several stores along the highway
She strung her thoughts together coherently

definitions: remove covering clothing or outer layer from something
take away all possessions rights or titles from someone
remove all clothes from oneself or make someone remove clothes
remove paint varnish or surface covering from furniture or walls
examples: Strip the bark from the branch before carving
The storm stripped leaves from the trees
The court stripped him of his medical license
They stripped the prisoners of their dignity
The doctor asked him to strip for the examination
The guards stripped the inmates for inspection
We need to strip the old paint before repainting
She stripped the antique dresser to restore it

definitions: mark something with long bands of contrasting color or texture
decorate or paint something with parallel bands or lines
examples: The artist striped the canvas with bold colors
Nature striped the zebra with black and white
They striped the parking lot for better organization
She striped the walls with alternating paint colors

definitions: make great efforts to achieve or obtain something difficult
struggle or fight vigorously against difficulties to reach a goal
examples: Students strive for excellence in their studies
The company strives to improve customer satisfaction
Athletes strive against their limitations every day
She strived to overcome her childhood trauma

definitions: move hand gently and repeatedly over a surface especially fur or hair
move oars through water to propel a boat forward
hit a ball smoothly and deliberately in sports like golf or tennis
examples: She gently stroked the cat's soft fur
He stroked her hair to comfort her
The team stroked their boat to victory
They stroked steadily across the lake
The golfer stroked the ball into the hole
She stroked a perfect backhand down the line

definitions: walk in a slow relaxed manner without hurry or effort
achieve something easily without much effort or difficulty
examples: The couple strolled through the park hand in hand
We strolled along the beach at sunset
The team strolled to victory against weak opponents
She strolled through the exam with confidence

definitions: organize or arrange something according to a system or plan
give a pattern or organization to something abstract like ideas or activities
examples: Teachers structure lessons to maximize student learning
The company restructured its departments for efficiency
She structured her argument with clear logical points
They structured the program around three main themes

definitions: engage in physical fight or combat with someone using force
make forceful or violent efforts to break free from restraint
experience difficulty and make great effort to accomplish something
examples: The two men struggled over the weapon
She struggled with her attacker in the alley
The prisoner struggled against his chains
The bird struggled to escape from the net
Students struggle with complex mathematical problems
Small businesses struggle to compete with corporations

definitions: play a stringed instrument by moving fingers across strings casually
produce a continuous rhythmic sound by repeated striking or vibrating
examples: He strummed his guitar while sitting by the campfire
She absently strummed a few chords
Rain strummed against the window panes
His fingers strummed nervously on the table

definitions: walk with a proud confident gait showing off to others
provide structural support as a bar or beam in construction
examples: The rooster strutted around the farmyard
He strutted across the stage like a rock star
Steel beams strut the building frame
The engineer strutted the bridge for extra support

definitions: accidentally strike toe or foot against something hard causing pain
extinguish a cigarette by pressing it against a surface
examples: She stubbed her toe on the coffee table
He stubbed his foot on a rock while hiking
Please stub out your cigarette before entering
He stubbed the cigarette in the ashtray

definitions: apply a plaster coating to exterior walls for weather protection
decorate walls or ceilings with ornamental plaster work
examples: They decided to stucco the exterior walls
The contractor will stucco the house next week
Artisans stuccoed the ceiling with elaborate designs
They stuccoed the archways with decorative patterns

definitions: decorate or reinforce something with metal studs or similar objects
use a male animal especially a horse for breeding purposes
examples: She studded the leather jacket with silver studs
They studded the door with decorative nails
The farmer uses his prize bull to stud
They stud horses at the ranch

definitions: devote time and attention to learning a subject through reading and practice
examine or investigate something carefully and in detail
conduct formal research into a subject to gain deeper understanding
examples: She studies medicine at the university
Students study for hours before exams
Scientists study the effects of climate change
He studied her face for signs of emotion
Researchers study cancer cells in the laboratory
The team will study consumer behavior patterns

definitions: fill a space or container tightly with material or objects
push or force something roughly into a confined space
eat large amounts of food quickly and greedily
examples: She stuffed the pillow with feathers
They stuffed newspapers into the cracks
He stuffed his clothes into the suitcase
Don't stuff everything in one drawer
The children stuffed themselves with candy
He stuffed his face at the buffet

definitions: trip or momentarily lose balance while walking or running
speak or read in a hesitant faltering way making mistakes
find or encounter something by chance without looking for it
examples: She stumbled on the uneven pavement
The drunk man stumbled down the street
The nervous student stumbled through his presentation
She stumbled over the difficult pronunciation
Hikers stumbled upon ancient ruins in the forest
I stumbled across an interesting article online

definitions: perplex or baffle someone completely with a difficult question or problem
walk heavily and stiffly typically due to injury or disability
travel around making political speeches during an election campaign
examples: The final question stumped all the contestants
This math problem has me completely stumped
He stumped around on his wooden leg
The injured player stumped off the field
The candidate stumped across the state
Politicians stump for votes before elections

definitions: knock unconscious or into a dazed state with a blow or impact
shock or astonish someone so greatly they are temporarily unable to react
examples: The blow to his head stunned him briefly
The electric shock stunned the fish
The news of her death stunned the community
His resignation announcement stunned everyone

definitions: prevent proper growth or development of something
perform dangerous or difficult feats for entertainment or publicity
examples: Poor nutrition stunted the child's growth
Lack of sunlight stunts plant development
The actor stunts in his own action movies
Daredevils stunt for circus audiences

definitions: speak with involuntary repetition or prolongation of sounds
operate or function with irregular repeated interruptions
examples: He stuttered nervously during the interview
The child stutters when excited or anxious
The engine stuttered before finally starting
The old computer stutters when running programs

definitions: design or arrange something in a particular fashionable way
designate with a particular name title or description
examples: She styles hair for fashion shows
The designer styled the room minimally
He styles himself as an expert
The company styles its products as luxury items

definitions: act as a substitute for someone who is absent or unavailable
work temporarily in place of the regular person in a job
examples: Can you sub for me at tomorrow's meeting?
She subbed for the math teacher all week
He subs at different schools when needed
I subbed for three months at that company
